awd_titl_txt: UNS: Establishing Elementary Mechanisms of Biomass and Hemicellulose Torrefaction
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Phillip R. Westmoreland
Proposal Number: 1512401

The transportation of woody biomass to a central processing facility for conversion into useful liquid fuels can be costly, particularly in sparsely populated rural areas.  Torrefaction is process that reduces the weight and volume of plant biomass to a form which can be transported more easily.  In torrefaction, harvested biomass is heated in the absence of air at 200 to 300 degrees Celsius to create a dense bio-oil rich feedstock.  However, this material is not very well characterized and contains a wide variety of compounds in gas, liquid, and solid forms.  This project will develop a comprehensive mathematical model for the torrefaction of biomass that will predict the energy requirements and final product mixture, using knowledge of the detailed reaction processes.  This model will then be used to develop torrefaction processes that can be tailored to make an energy-dense, low-oxygen material from woody biomass.  Research results will be used to provide examples in engineering classes at undergraduate and graduate levels, and to enable the development of classroom materials on biofuel topics for high school students through the involvement of high school teachers in research.

The goal of this research is to develop a comprehensive model for the elementary reactions and kinetics during the torrefaction of the hemicellulose fraction of woody biomass.  In torrefaction, the biomass is heated in an inert atmosphere at 200 to 300 degrees C.  It is hypothesized that pericyclic reactions, which are known to describe cellulose pyrolysis accurately, also describe the torrefaction of hemicellulose.  The model will be developed using reaction kinetics experiments, computational quantum chemistry, and reaction theory.  Thermogravimetric analyses will provide instantaneous heats of pyrolysis.  Product gases and vapors will be profiled in real time by two-dimensional gas chromatography with time-of-flight mass spectrometry (GCxGC-TOFMS).  These experiments will be carried out with solid samples of woody biomass (loblolly pine), the hemicellulose biopolymers xylan and galactoglucomannan, and hemicellulose monomers xylose, arabinose, mannose, and galactose.  The reaction processes for the flash pyrolysis of the torrefied solids will be studied by online GCxGC-TOFMS analysis of the bio-oil product vapors, complimented by analysis of the residual solid structures using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR).  Quantum-chemistry analyses of monomer torrefaction will be expected to yield additional mechanistic insights.  The full model will predict reaction kinetics and products of the torrefaction of cellulose and hemicellulose fractions of woody biomass.  Educational activities based on the research include mentoring of an undergraduate process design team on the design of a thermochemical biomass processing plant, development of course materials for reaction kinetics and transport courses at the undergraduate and graduate levels, and research experiences for undergraduates and high school teachers.

por.por_cntn:
Torrefaction is a gentle heating (200-300°C) that removes much of the oxygen from woody biomass, mainly breaking down its hemicelluose portion and creating a far better feedstock for making bio-derived chemicals and fuels. This project's research established elementary reaction steps for hemicellulose torrefaction, in particular identifying key reactions as being pericyclic conversions. These are non-ionic, non-radical reactions that remove oxygen as water vapor and CO2, while beginning the breakdown of the hemicellulose polymer into smaller fragments that can be turned into oils at higher temperatures.

Woody biomass is largely made up of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin components. Lignin has its own pathways, but hemicellulose is chemically similar to cellulose. Both are polymers of ring-shaped sugar molecules, but in cellulose, one type of sugar ring molecules, glucose, is strung together in single strands; in hemicellulose, many chemically differing sugar molcules are strung together, the strings may branch, and the ring sugars may have differing side groups like carboxylic acids. Also, the sugars and their proportions can differ from plant to plant, making hemicellulose much more varied in chemical structure than glucose. Lignin differs chemically from both cellulose and hemicellulose, but it may be chemically bonded to hemicellulose molecules.

The project's approach was to attack the question through combined experiments and computational chemistry. Two types of torrefaction experiments were performed, using selected sugar monomers, short polysaccharide strands (oligomers), and whole hemicellulose, extracted from wood. In TGA/DSC, the first type of experiment, sample temperatures were raised at a modest rate like 10°C/min to a prechosen end temperature. During heating, the sample was continuously weighed (TGA) and heat flow to the sample was measured as the steady temperature rise was maintained (DSC). In Pyrolysis-GCMS, the second type of experiment, the samples were heated rapidly to some temperature, and composition of the released vapors and gases were analyzed using two-dimensional gas chromatography / time-of-flight mass spectrometry (GCxGC-TOFMS). This analysis method is used to separate the complex mixtures for species identification and quantification.

A key component of hemicellulose is xylan, a polymer of the monosaccharide xylose. Both the monomer and the polymer were pyrolyzed, revealing common features and selectivity differences. The products are divided into three categories: (1) Products that are identified in all cases, including H2O, CO2, formic acid, formaldehyde, glycolaldehyde, acetal, acetic acid, dihydroxyacetone, furanmethanol, furfural, 2-(5H)-furanone, and ethanediol diacetate; (2) Products identified only from D-xylose torrefaction, including 4-cyclopentene-1,3-dione and furancarboxaldehyde; and (3) Products identified only from xylan torrefaction, including methanol, ethanol, propionic acid, butyrolactone, dianhydro-3-methylene-2,5-furandione, 2-hydroxy-3-ethyl-2-cyclopenten-1-one, 2-cyclohexen-1-one, and γ-carboethoxy-γ-butyrolactone.

One of the major experimental products of xylose torrefaction is furfural, which is not easily explained by the direct reactions from xylose, in contrast to other major products like glycolaldehyde or dihydroxyacetone. Extensive investigation of this mechanism has shown it to be a complex network, constrained by the chiral specificity of saccharide structures and involving a large number of interconnected, parallel reaction pathways. Over 70 intermediate species and over 150 distinct transition states were identified computationally. Several of the most promising pathways depend on the ring-contraction class of transitions we discovered.

As another key result, equilibria and kinetics were calculated for the monosaccharide anomers. Each chemically different sugar has five different "anomeric" structures: acyclic, a 5-member oxygen-containing ring (furanoses), a 6-member oxygen-containing ring (pyranoses), and two different chiral positions of the -OH group on carbon 1 of the ring forms. Modeling revealed the favored stuctures of each sugar and how the mix of anomers changes with temperature.
